text:
Flushing River (Queens): An early view of the river, also known as Flushing Creek, when it still had a rural aspect.

View 2 is north from Roosevelt Avenue across the Whitestone spur bridge of the Long Island Railroad and the Northern Boulevard vehicular bridge(twin stone anchorages). An old roadside hotel can be seen at the left end of the bridge..

View 3 shows the east bank of the river, looking south toward the Northern Boulevard Bridge.

Views 1,2: Eugene L.Armbruster Collection

View 3: P.L. SPERR

View 1: 1897
View 2: 1924

July 16, 1937
title: Flushing Creek [Flushing River] - Queens - [Northern Boulevard Bridge.]

July 16, 1937
title: Flushing Creek [Flushing River] - Queens - [Northern Boulevard Bridge.]

text:
Flushing River (Queens): South along the creek from Northern Boulevard, showing the busy barge traffic that is carried on here. The Roosevelt Avenue draw bridge, which carries the B.M.T. and I.R.T. subways, can be seen in the background of views 1 and 2. In the foreground of view 1 is the Whitestone spur of the Long Island Railroad, gone in 1935. View 3 is north from the Whitestone railroad spur and shows the Northern Boulevard draw bridge.

P. L. Sperr

View 1: April 8, 1927
View 2: October 5, 1935
View 3: March 12, 1932
title: Flushing River - Queens - [Northern Boulevard Bridge.]

title: Flushing River - Queens - [Northern Boulevard Bridge.]

text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): Three views of the northern portion of the park before it was transformed into the grounds of the New York World's Fair, 1939-40. The dirt roads lead north toward Northern Boulevard from the dumps at Roosevelt Avenue, between Grand Central Parkway and Willetts Point Boulevard.

Views 1,2; September 30, 1935
View 3: October 5, 1935

P. L. Sperr

view 2-3
title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - [Between Grand Central Parkway and Willets Point Boulevard.]

title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - [Between Grand Central Parkway and Willets Point Boulevard.]

text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): Flowers and pampa grass in the upper part of the park, between Roosevelt Avenue and Northern Boulevard. Views 2 and 3 show a drainage ditch in the same area. The New York World's Fair, 1939-40, completely transformed this area several years later.

View 1: September 30, 1935
Views 2,3: October 1, 1935

P. L. Sperr
title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - [Roosevelt Avenue - Northern Boulevard.]

title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - [Roosevelt Avenue - Northern Boulevard.]

text:
Flushing River (Queens), south from Northern Boulevard, showing coal and stone and gravel yards, the Roosevelt Avenue subway bridge, and the World's Fair under construction (view 2) and completed. View 1 is south from the Roosevelt Avenue bridge across the Long Island Railroad trestle. The area below the railroad is the Corona dumps, site of the World's Fair of 1939-40.

P. L. Sperr

View 1: Sept. 30, 1935
View 2: May 30, 1938
View 3: May 27, 1939
title: Flushing River - Queens - [Northern Boulevard.]

title: Flushing River - Queens - [Northern Boulevard.]

text:
Flushing River, north from Roosevelt Avenue. In the center background, just below Northern Boulevard, is the W. & J. Sloan furniture factory. View 3 shows the Tisdale Company's coal silos, on the east bank of the river, just below Roosevelt Avenue,

P. L. Sperr

September 30, 1935
Views 1,2,3
title: Flushing River - Queens - Roosevelt Avenue - [W. J. Sloan Furniture Company - Tisdale Lumber and Coal Company.]

title: Flushing River - Queens - Roosevelt Avenue - [W. J. Sloan Furniture Company - Tisdale Lumber and Coal Company.]

text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): Three views in a southeasterly direction across the north end of the park lying between Roosevelt Avenue and Flushing Bay. This area is being constructed into large automobile parking spaces for visitors to the New York World's Fair 1939-40. In the background is the I. R. T. and B. M. T. subway "El" on Roosevelt Avenue; in the foreground is Grand Central Parkway (view 2) and on the extreme left (view 3) is Northern Boulevard and Flushing Bay. In the distant background is Flushing.

October 21, 1936
Views 1,2,3

P. L. Sperr
title: Queens: Flushing Meadow Park - [Roosevelt Avenue - Flushing Bay.]
